title: Before 13 January 2022, will H.R.5376, also known as the Build Back Better Act, become law?
preds: Came too late to truly forecast. The likelihood of this happening in the next 16 hours is nill. Could have been convinced to predict a ~20% probability a few weeks back given the pro/cons at the time: (+) optimistic negotiations on a $1.5 trn version, (-) Manchin's office's comments on the climate investments (e.g. threatening "grid reliability"), (-) Manchin's antagonism of the childcare tax credit which is a hard line for progressives.

Shoot.  I failed to adjust to it being 2022 and thought of this as "next January".  I have been skeptical about the ability to land this bill since early December.  I believe it the democrats need to have a "success" well before the mid-terms but could imagine it getting too close for comfort.
If an amended bill counts it stands to reason that the Executive will find some compromise version of the bill that will pass.

This is a "must pass" for Democrats.  I believe they will pass something with the name "Build Back Better" and they will tout it as a significant accomplishment. It is almost certain that the current version will not pass.  The question then is how significantly it will need to be amended.

No, the Biden administration recognizes that Build Back Better can be done later, only if they survive the midterms. Surviving the midterms against historical trends would require the voting rights bills currently being considered to be signed into law. There is a concerted effort to rally the votes around the MLK Jr. holiday for messaging purposes. Therefore, I do not think that the Biden administration is making BBB a priority right now. Additional evidence to support this is that in December, Majority Leader Schumer promised a vote on the BBB Act to pressure Senator Manchin and threaten him with an official vote on his record on which he could be attacked. I have not read anywhere about the planned vote. It is my suspicion that Leader Manchin and President Biden are trying to ease tensions with Senator Manchin so that he would be more likely to go against his previous stance and vote for a filibuster carveout to pass the voting rights bills. Additionally, because of recent reporting and media appearances by folks like Stacey Abrams, the messaging seems to be centered around voting rights and tying that effort to January 6th. Passing both large pieces of legislation in a dual track would be a nearly insurmountable task for the Biden administration, especially considering his low approval rating.
I understand it depends on one person's vote (Joe Manchin) with pressure from both sides. It seems a 50/50 to me.
No change is the stalemate. Inflation is beginning to scare even the Democrats.
Late entry here, but I can’t see a way through on this Act given the surrounding turmoil.
Negociations for a new deal will take more time.

There have been no conversations or negotiations with Manchin. There is "currently, neither Build Back Better nor filibuster reform has the Democratic backing needed to move forward. To make progress on either issue, the party will need to overcome long stalemates"
Focus is on addressing the filibuster and other matters. The Senate won't pass it and the President won't sign it (required for it to become law) within the next 8 days.
was on the fence as to whether this was closer to 1% or 0%, but @smingers ' comment pushed me toward 0%: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1378562

Trawled through through senate.gov,  congress.gov etc to get a sense of the voting schedule, but there is nothing on the calendar at the moment since presumably any *scheduled event* is conditional on Manchin agreeing to support. At the time of writing this, there is some news of negotiations reopening, but experience tells us, we shouldn't expect anything substantial in the next ten days. Dems definitely don't want another public failure, so they would proceed cautiously.  For all practical purposes, the chances are zero - but I should pop back in, if things change in a hurry.
With the 1/6 anniversary this week, required consensus between House and Senate versions, and Democratic hold outs, BBB is not going to be signed into law by the question deadline.
Updating up on the news that Manchin is back at the table today.
There is no way the Senate will complete the necessary back and forth that will certainly be required in order for it to pass.
There is not enough political unity or will to pass the law before the question deadline

The Democrat Party does not have a mandate of support for such sweeping social changes to existing policy.  They have overplayed what little mandate they had with serious consequences to our economic and energy sectors.
it will take a lot longer to come to an agreement, if it ever does.
This bill will take more months before being passed in a watered down and less expensive version or defeated.

I give it a 50-50 chance. It looks like it might only get through if Biden can pick off a few Republican senators, or he comprises on his proposals. Either one could happen and he'll be determined to get it through before the midterms. All of this means it could happen, even if it looks unlikely right now.
It is just barely possible in the time remaining to remove enough to get it to pass the Senate, toss it back to the House to approve the changes and then get it signed.

There is still a lot of work to be done before an acceptable bill can pass the Senate - it has low chances of passing before January 13th, but it has a better chance of passing jn the first two months of 2022.
An amended version for less cost will pass.
Manchin has killed it, the only way they pass it is with a significantly scaled back version, but it wouldn’t be the same bill
This won't happen for months, if it happens at all.

I can actually see a tiny chance of Manchin reverses course in the next day or two, but honestly I neglected this question for a bit too long and now need to drop it to 0 to make up for the hurt to my own score.
The fractious nature of the political system and parties within America make them likelihood of this contentious item being law, slim.
Joe Manchin has not given any indication that he will budge on his position.

While this will not pass before the first of the year, it appears Manchin has shown a willingness to negotiate on certain issues. I believe an amended version for less money and more concessions is a possibility
The stalling, poor media coverage and lack of confidence make me think Democrats will go back to the drawing board after a loss.
Running out of days at this point with Democrats in the Senate publicly stating that they will not sign it. Would require a blitz to get this in before the 13.
Prove me wrong, Democrats. I dare you! (please…)
Recent press releases indicate one of the key swing votes to pass the law, Democratic Sen. Joe Manchin, will not support the Build Back Better Act in its current state.

In hindsight, I gave too much weight to this passing based on Manchin's voting record which is consistently with Biden. I didn't factor in that votes which he would likely dissent on were never held since the Democrcrats would certainly lose the vote if he was to. Hard to see how after this weeks statement from Manchin there will be enough progress once the Senate returns to make the necessary progress to resolve this as 'yes'.
Based Manchin’s latest comments I don’t see much chance of this occurring in the time frame
According to numerous reports, the relationship between the WH & Manchin has soured.  On Fox today, Manchin said he was a "No" vote.
Looking at my original comment on November 27, seems to be coming to fruition.
already dragging on for too long for any party to move to compromise.
Despit Manchin’s opposition, there is still a chance for compromise.
Updating lower to incorporate Manchin's comments today. Looks like a Hail Mary is the only chance of a January passage.

https://www.nytimes.com/2021/12/19/us/politics/manchin-build-back-better.html “It remains to be seen whether they [Democrats] will respond by significantly modifying the bill in the hopes of salvaging something that can pass.” I don’t think it remains to be seen whether they will do so by mid-January. The small print of our Question states: “An amended H.R.5376 becoming law would count.” I’m therefore maintaining a 1% chance of some kind of “fig leaf” bill passing, that accomplishes some small percentage of BBB’s initial intent. History won’t be kind to Manchin. The lives of many “non-elite” Americans would’ve been most substantially improved by a number of important provisions of this bill. And yet, it seems like plenty of voters with the most to gain would instead prefer to see America’s social fabric continue to atrophy, and they will probably cheer this failure—at least in the short term.

Down 14. Apparently Manchin is saying he is done with BBB. https://twitter.com/alexanderbolton/status/1472569121665695753 Don't know what that means exactly, but seems very unlikely it goes anywhere by the resolution date.

Coming a little lower to be more in line with my past reasoning regarding this question's time constraints. Below consensus but above where I think is the "true" probability, which is near 5% plus or minus a few.

Reaffirming. My forecast seems to be in the middle of where most people with generous reasoning are saying. May have to drop due to @MeanJean's finding that Skopos Labs puts this at 10% chance of it passing (I would assume without time restrictions like this question has). This is above average for a bill but still unlikely. I would assume because there are restrictions in this question, the probability for passing consistent with this question's timeframe is 5% or lower.

According to Skopos Labs, the bill as passed by the House has a 10 percent chance of being in enacted into law. (source: https://www.jdsupra.com/legalnews/the-build-back-better-act-was-passed-in-1182959/). Another factor is that there are less than 5 sessions left for Senate to try to vote on this.  I googled through the U.S. senate records to see what was being discussed (that site is not intuitive for researching status of acts), it does seem contested by republicans but democrats felt confident it would be signed into law by Christmas. Since then natural disasters and other higher "news" items seemingly are being worked now. https://www.senate.gov/legislative/bills_acts_laws.htm
The democrats have punted this for 2021. They may pass the bill, but not before Jan 13th, 2022.

I wanna say 8% or lower but Congress really can get things moving the days they reconvene. Have to remember it's almost 2 weeks to get it done after this year ends. A lot can happen when they get back.
It seems like they're far from agreement on it. -25

https://apnews.com/article/joe-biden-business-voting-rights-joe-manchin-congress-d974a9fa170d32a609c96145a4076e65
some version of this will probably pass some day, but not by 13 january

"A source familiar with the discussions told NBC News that talks between Biden and Machin have been going “very poorly” and they are “far apart” on the proposal."
https://www.cnbc.com/2021/12/15/build-back-better-act-democrats-unlikely-to-pass-biden-social-spending-plan.html "The sources make clear the conversations will continue and that missing the Christmas deadline doesn't mean the bill itself is dead. White House officials have been working through several different options to present to Manchin they view as an effort to thread the needle. But at the moment, any near-term resolution appears unlikely." https://www.cnn.com/2021/12/15/politics/manchin-child-tax-credit-biden-build-back-better/index.html You'd think given my time in the political sphere I'd know these things almost never happen in the desired timeframe but it seems I'm consistently too optimistic on these questions...
Adjusting up a bit on the expectation that the Senate will continue to meet until Christmas, bucking the planned recess.

After
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tornado_outbreak_of_December_10%E2%80%9311,_2021 ,
what could be better than "more money" for "more and better infrastructure"?

https://www.cnn.com/2021/12/10/politics/biden-manchin-vote/index.html I’m now monitoring for an announcement that Manchin’s on board. I expect further changes to BBB will take weeks and weeks. The Question timeframe doesn’t allow for this.
Passage of time, + with inflation this bad one wonders if Biden himself is not starting to doubt the wisdom of passing even more stimulus

The Dole legacy essay, a punch in the face of Mitch McConnell, and
omicron, which is going to necessitate a pre-emptive strike against an economic downturn due to a next wave (and a possible necessary lock down, in case omicron proves to be able to fully evade immunity acquired by vaccination...) and the impact of tightening the Federal Reserve policies

In passing the house, BBB has likely braved its gauntlet. With such a polarized senate, it seems more likely then unlikely that holdouts like Manchin will be driven back to their side of the line, if only to stay the wrath of the democratic party.

Following the crowd a bit and tilting to lean a bit against. Seems very unlikely by the end of year especially given Senate time off for the holidays. But possible that they get it sorted out in the week or two back in the new year.

Byrd Rule will mean that the climate portion of HR5376 will be found to be in non-compliance. Without that provision, I cannot see many of the Moderately Progressive to deeply Progressive senators voting for this legislation, meaning it is DOA until the other bill(s) related to Progressive priorities get signed into law. All this to say, we can hope but see a narrow path forward unless Chuck casts aside those Democrat holdouts in the hopes of picking up enough votes from across the aisle.
There are serious impediments due to inflation

Chances decrease with each passing day. Inflation fears are increasing and people are focused on other things right now. The Progressive wing tried to tie to infrastructure bill to BBB knowing the former had a better chance than the latter. Once the Infrastructure bill passed stand alone, it made it easier for BBB to fail

The Senate is not in session from December 11th through the rest of 2021. I wasn't able to find a January 2022 Senate calendar, but in January 2021 the Senate met for only two days before January 13th. I'm looking now at the data from voteview.com, but cutting it off at 2010. In general, of bills that eventually pass, about 77% pass within 55 days. What are the odds that the bill will eventually pass? I should think quite high- let's say about 90%, so that takes us to about 70%. That feels really, really high. Maybe the real question is just, period, what are the odds that a bill passes between Dec 7 (today) and January 13. Looks like about 25 have done. But of all the bills that have already taken 18 days, the gap between House and Senate passage is well over 100 days. So maybe the question is-- what's the distribution of bills that have already passed 18 days since House passage? Looks like there's only a 40% chance they pass within 55 if they've already taken 18. So I'll treat that as an update.

Democratize support with sen. Manchin and Senima support still unlikely in current form.  Compromise and readjustment will likely take place and then get enacted.  Interest groups will put pressure that will increase likelihood of passage.

https://www.businessinsider.com/house-democrats-biden-spending-bill-monthly-child-tax-credit-expires-2021-12?amp Adjusting initial forecast for passage of time without any positive indications that things are headed to a senate vote soon (and plenty of indications to the contrary).
It has before a last remaining major policy with too many forces wanting to extract their own benefits, rather than simply voting on their views of the bill

Low probability. The negotiations appear to be fractured as different wings of the Democratic party are opposed on key components of the bill. I believe the bill may be passed in 2022 but not before Jan 13th.

Joe Manchin and Kyrsten Synema will be tough votes to get but I think the Democrats can whip their votes along with some Republican support, although there will probably be some change to the bill for that to happen.

If you consider that only 66 out of 10,919 total proposed bills and resolutions in the 117th Congress were enacted or signed into law, that would give you a very low base rate of 0.6% (https://www.govtrack.us/congress/bills/statistics). However, this bill is a very high-profile bill with significant presidential backing and emphasis making it more likely to be passed. One drawback, on the other hand, is the tight window given in the question of 13 January especially given the upcoming holiday recess and the fact that the Senate is not likely to resume business until about 6 January or later. If the question time frame were pegged to the end of January, more than likely before the President gives a State of the Union address, I would say the odds would be higher that at least a modified form of HR5376 would be signed into law. I am going to give this a slightly better than 50/50 chance at 55% likely to happen.

It seems the act is almost certain to pass, so it's mostly a matter of time. The Senate breaks Dec 13 for the year, so there's only 5 days left in 2021... I can't find when they resume sitting so am unclear on how much time there will be for discussion before the question ends in January. And it comes down to Manchin's support on starting debate. There are several other issues now on the table (debt ceiling). It seems likely that, if pushed, Machin will support it, so it depends whether Schumer feels confident in pushing him. As usual it will probably be an 11th hour decision, so if it happens will likely be late this week. I'll give it 2-1 but am not confident enough to go past that.

Found two, completely at odds, articles on this today:
https://edition.cnn.com/2021/12/02/politics/joe-manchin-biden-build-back-better/index.html
- Manchin doubts it will get passed this year
- Democratic 'source' says 20-25% chance it will pass
https://www.thestreet.com/personal-finance/taxes/build-back-better-likely-to-pass-senate-later-this-month-analysts
- Analysts at conservative thinktank American Enterprise say it looks very likely to pass this year Sounds to me like the first article's source is trying to give Manchin more negotiating power. The second article on the other hand probably has an interest in teeing up chances so that if it fails to get done this year, it looks like a disaster. Speculation that the bill will reach a vote w/c 13th December. I still back my original forecast that this is likely to happen and Manchin likely to vote it through. Regardless of him being perceived as a 'centrist' it's easier for him to win re-election if the Democrats are doing well and torpedoing this bill will make that harder. Question mark will be around the inflation number released on December 10th. I think if it goes above 7% then this looks less likely to be resolved as yes.

The current bill will change, but there is much pressure to approve this bill. The administration plans to expalin it in more detail, often and in plainlanguage as to benefits,. Much of the bill is very popular.
the back room deal -normally going on in this cases-  in the right wing is based on who can vote yes and be re-elected, so it will pass.....
1) "An amended H.R.5376 becoming law would count"
think it still gets passed, but seems likely to slip into mid-january already and any other delays with other congressional items or new events would push it to later january
Outlier is Manchin, completely unpredictable.  My sense is it will but with more carve backs.
All reportage indicated Christmas passage, intense pressure to go home for the holidays by hurrying up and getting it done.
Bill has been worked on for months and has less than a month left counting Christmas break. Also Dems have to feel increasingly nervous about passing more stimulus during persistent inflation.

** Base rate for this Congress so far 65 passed/227 got a vote o 27% but Big Biden push
last congress 344/714 (48%)
https://www.govtrack.us/congress/bills/statistics **
https://www.jdsupra.com/legalnews/house-passes-build-back-better-act-here-8749787/ The U.S. House of Representatives has passed the Build Back Better Act (BBBA) (H.R. 5376) by a vote of 220–213. Supported by the Biden Administration and congressional Democrats, the controversial bill heads to the Senate for a vote. While the BBBA is expected to undergo significant changes during Senate review (and may not pass at all)
it will probably be amended and pass
The omicron variant and the next kick the can down the street of the budget will distract attention from the bill and push it later.
Too many unsolved hurdles at this point. The stars need to align for it to pass. Possible, but unlikely.

There are a half dozen Democrat senators who have expressed concern over the price tag or potential price tag of even the scaled back bill.  Although they will be under immense pressure, there is a good chance that at least one will vote no.  The Republicans will remain solid in opposition.

I suspect that the possibility of one or more spanners being thrown into the works is greater than most people realize. There is much that must go right for this proposal to actually become law, and thus multiple points of failure. The infrastructure act barely passed, and only after months of super-human effort for what should have been a "slam-dunk" quick action - and indeed, should have been done years ago. I see little cause for optimism.
This Act will become law because it has more pros than cons that Republicans will attempt to spin as their contribution to create momentum for the midterms.

The GOP has sought to limit several aspects of pork spending by Dems, however, the independents and far left has begun doubting the administration's prior commitments and will seek to challenge the democratic establishment, while asserting their relevance making it extremely difficult for policy makers to come to qn agreement.
Base rate for bills passing Congress is 1-3%, and I give this a 2x chance to pass. Rounding to 5% for a clean number

Strongly doubt it, Republican obstructionism and the Democrats resistance to killing the filibuster (combined with some Dem Senators reluctance to back the legislation in the Senate) will likely doom the law.

Republicans will have a sudden "change of heart" after the first of the year, when a new elections season comes into their myopic view.  They certainly wouldn't want to be seen as "the party of 'No'" during such a crucial time.
The Democrats think they need this to survive.  Manchin and Sinema will get more points for amending than killing.  Only the calendar makes this less than 100%.
It would be a pretty sure thing except for Kirsten Synema.
Keeps getting pushed back, was supposed to be in for the COP26 summit, but failed. Suspect it'll keep failing a bit more.

Every republican senator will vote against it.  The moderate end of the democratic senators (e.g. Joe Manchin) will continue to protest the over-reaches by the progressive end of the party.  I don't think the moderate senators feel any sense of time pressure to reach a compromise.  Senators will be additionally spoked by Omicron, inflation concerns, and the gamesmanship of avoiding a government shutdown.

The Democratic leadership has been consistent in saying they want a deal done by Christmas. However, government shutdown, NDAA, inflation, COVID concerns, recent election results, and increasing concerns with China weigh heavy on legislation moving through. Increasing the potential is the bill being pushed to the Senate via the reconciliation process. This will prevent Senate filibuster. The 50 democrats (the two independents are with the democratic caucus) with VP Harris breaking tie can push this legislation without 60 votes. Machin and Sinema and are a little bit of a wildcard in the situation, but their voting record has been supportive of Joe Biden. Reconciliation also allows the bill to have unlimited amendments by both Democratic and Republicans, which increases the opportunity to for the bill to pass with dramatic alterations (https://www.crefc.org/cre/content/News/Items/advocacy-items/_House_Passes_BBB_but_Senate_May_Not_Pass_before_Yearend.aspx)

Any version of the bill that past will need to be reconciled in Conference Committee. There is probably not enough time for it to pass before Jan. 13th. The midterm calculus in this is irrelevant, they may think it is important but passing it is not likely to help them, and not passing it will only hurt them with base enthusiasm. So both their deadline and this one here is less important for its ultimate passage.

An amended H.R.5376 becoming law would count. The two question marks in the senate for this are Joe Manchin and Krysten Sinema. They have criticised the bill but so far their voting records show they pretty much always support Biden: https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/biden-congress-votes/joe-manchin/
https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/biden-congress-votes/kyrsten-sinema/ Multiple senators are saying this will be done before Christmas
https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/inflation-concerns-mount-republicans-democrats-odds-build-back/story?id=81422341
https://www.cnbc.com/2021/11/16/chuck-schumer-says-senate-aims-to-pass-biden-build-back-better-plan-by-christmas.html Biden will waste no time signing this once it's passed. Risks:
- 1 or both senate holdouts will either never vote for this or will delay into next year (I think given their records this is unlikely. Maybe 5%)
- Government shutdown at the start of December isn't averted and that starts to dominate the agenda (https://www.reuters.com/markets/us/us-house-leaders-float-short-term-fix-fund-govt-into-jan-punchbowl-2021-11-29/ gives some security on this since it will take it beyond question expiry but there is still a risk here, estimate 10%). 
- Some other legislative emergency appears, eg. covid emergency if Omicron is particularly problematic (I think by the time this is clear the bill would hopefully have passed so I think this is <5%) Overall think this is likely to go through. The Democrats have set their Christmas goal and anything that takes them beyond this is going to start hurting them in the mid-terms.

Leaning heavy towards yes for now will wait to hear what major hurdles could cause delays in the upcoming weeks. With Democrats having the majority it should be slightly easier to pass in the Senate. It’s still politics so the potential for adjustments will exist. Following the past major updates on the bill it was in the House 9-27 to 11-19 for it to pass the Senate it would cover roughly the same timespan about 37ish working days -the Senate are also capable of showing up on the weekend to vote so there’s still a decent amount of time left.

If it passes it will be significantly changed in the Senate and I do not believe the House will be able to reconcile the changes that quickly. I think the probability that it moves through the Senate under reconciliation is less than 50%.

The House passed the bill Nov 17 and the Build Back Better package now heads to the Senate, where negotiations will continue.  I doubt the the Senate can pass the bill with a simple majority because certian centrist members,  like West Virginia Sen. Joe Manchin and Arizona Sen. Kyrsten Sinema, have signaled that they are not ready to vote. Sen Manchin in particulare is worried about inflation, and wants to talk to more people about it. The could  wield enormous power to alter the text of the bill meaning it will have to be sent back to the House for reconsideration.  Biden has lobbied both senators but neither has publicly made clear exactly what they want, it appears to be a stalemate.  The process is very complex and each step has the potential to push the deadline back, well into the new year. There are also more pressing matters for the Senate to attend to most notabley funding the government and finding some pathway to raise or suspend the debt ceiling will be priorities when Senate returns following the Thanksgiving break. I tried to find how long, on average a bill takes to become law. There is no average timeline that one could use to complare. I also considered how many bills become law on average annually (108) and how many the 117th congress have passed (65 public) ps://www.congress.gov/browse. Not sure this is very helpful.
Democratic reps will probably fall in line and vote for it. Failing to do so would be too big of a punishment for the party, and thus for their own self interest.

We'll see what happens when things come back on Monday: right now I don't feel like I have a ton to go off of here. The big thing I'll be looking at is the aversion of shutdown based on the spending cliff on the 3rd. If that goes badly (especially if there actually is a shutdown) then I'll downgrade my probability quite a bit- if the Democrats prove functional enough to get that through easily then I'd upgrade.

It took a while to pass the house where Democrats have a stronger majority, and the Senate is really where the final bill just be narrowly tailored to satisfy everyone so I think this timeline could be pretty tight. Leaning slightly yes.

National Democratic leadership seems consistent in saying they want a deal done by Christmas. This probably will slip over into the New Year anyway, and they still have to contend with the aversion of a govt shutdown and passage of a new NDAA. Were it not for these, my confidence would be higher, but the odds overall seem to have them on track for success.

Seems like Manchin and Sinema are the kingmakers. Betting the Drama kings drag it out.
In addition, there's the debt limit revisited on December 3 which causes default around Dec 15 without agreement or extension. But an extension would take some of the pressure off which then could lead to delays on passing the bill.

If this is to pass at all it must happen quickly before everyone gets involved in the fall campaign. Not passing this leaves democrats with little to talk about during the fall campaign. Yes the infrastructure billed passed but the public will not see any benefit for a while. 65% yes is my starting point but a big wild card is the new covid variant. If it is bad and it looks like it will disrupt the economies recovery then more federal stimulus will seem attract and I will raise my odds.
There will be distractions, like a new variant, at play.

Essential for US position towards foreign powers. The more they will focuse on foreign affairs espacially China, the more they need a solid home base with a descent economy to finance it. Inequality is the biggest issue here, this could be solved partly by an improvement of their infrastructure.

Subjective first forecast, based on a favored scenario where deliberations extend into January, but some form of 5376 becomes law before mid-January.
There isn’t a lot of spare time to get this done to trigger the question, and there is ample chance for progress to be delayed beyond the question timeframe.
https://www.marketwatch.com/story/here-are-the-hurdles-for-bidens-build-back-better-plan-when-the-senate-returns-11637939414
